Revised Review:
There is so much wrong with the game that breaking it out in detail is almost as un-fun as the game itself.

Rather than go into depth I’ll just indicate what bothers me as simply as possible.

Resources as cards and not tokens sucks. Spending cards to play one card feels unnecessary.

Villains with health per player is a lazy design choice and it shows in the game. Villains shouldn’t always be accessible every round and it would have been nice if there was a story component with objectives to complete to get to the villain. Having 2 levels of the villain to fight against feels very unoriginal and it shows because the the gameplay just drones on while you manage threat and attack the villain.

Cycling through a deck should not be a major staple and with cards as resources that is exactly the case. Having cards to cycle the deck can be made to be character or deck specific and other games do just fine with discard x cards to achieve that.

There isn’t any location or sense of setting that impacts game state and that really hurts theme because marvel is a big universe and this missing component really makes this game feel silly. You’re always fighting the villain every round somewhere and it feels like it really doesn’t matter because the location doesn’t impact the game and it really should.

Flipping to alter ego is a sensible component to add to the game but here it feels silly because your motivation is for healing and preventing damage and that’s really it. It just feels like there was more room here for for other game actions/decisions being in alter ego. Also games play better when action management is a thing. That only happens if there a finite number of actions and this game doesn’t limit your actions. And that is why it isn’t fun with >2 players. If you don’t believe me just watch Boggs play with Team Covenant team at TC’s Marvel event at their store with the kid and his dad. Boggs looked like he was playing his game for the first time with 4 people and realized just how boring it was. But I think therein lies the problem with this game.

Overall this game is sloppy. It feels like a high school project done one week before due date. This game’s design feels like it was designed by 3 kids who opted not to collaborate but instead came up with different ideas and pasted them together and turned in as complete. This game should never have left development and somehow this game made it past senior designers. This game was not ready. This IP has too much potential for this to be FFG’s offering. Just a boring mess of a game with great art work. It is absolutely stunning listening to people say they play 100s of sessions of this game. It is ok to tell FFG that this game was not good and to expect more. This game’s design is way below par for FFG. They missed a real opportunity to make a combo box of competitive and coop play too.
FFG is running out of ideas. They've taken elements from their previous LCGs and just rehashed them here. This is nothing but another money sink, and a boring one at that.

While on paper I should absolutely love solo LCGs, I have yet to find one that sticks. The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game was fiddly and the balance was off. I also disliked playing two-handed. Arkham Horror: The Card Game was excellent, but it sacrificed tight gameplay for cohesive narrative. When I heard Marvel Champions was both streamlined and puzzly it immediately piqued my interest

Unfortunately, Marvel Champions is not my holy grail, but it is pretty close and has the potential to expand to be one of my favorite games. So far I've played all of the core set villains through with Spider-Man as well as Captain Marvel against the harder version of Rhino. The scenario design (in the core set) is basic but fine. The turn-to-turn upkeep is extremely low which is great for me as a solo gamer. The turns are combo-y with lots of action stringing. There is a small amount of hand management in which cards you keep and which you use for paying costs

Unlike say Arkham Horror LCG, a lot of what happens in Marvel Champions is deterministic. I can plan out whether I have enough attack to defeat the villain next turn for example. This gives the game a leg up for me - I prefer a puzzle that lets me (for the most part) plan turns in advance over a game where my fate feels determined by random draws. This does mean the game lacks a bit of dynamicism. If I can near perfectly predict the villain's turn then things can tend to feel a little boring

Also unlike Arkham, the deckbuilding and card play is much more free. I find this both good and bad. Heroes aren't tied to specific colors but rather one of any color. This means there are many builds for every hero which is a neat aspect. The scenarios themselves are also modular which is fantastic. This game was designed with replay value in mind for sure

As far as theme goes there is basically no narrative in the game. I'm fine with this. I don't care about superheros but I do appreciate how many superheros and villains there are as that means lots of combinations

Overall the core set is great value. You get plenty of cards for deckbuilding and mix-matching - more so than any other LCG on the market by a wide margin. My only real complaint would be the rules reference which I find almost worthless - I've tried to look up rules many times to find that the word I was looking for was never referenced. Really basic terms are missing (e.g. "defeat", "round", "draw") and it feels like the rules reference was never user tested

So I like Marvel Champions. Variety is very high, but the gameplay is just good so far. I found Spider-Man to be pretty boring, but I'm liking Captain Marvel as she has more nuance. The villains are just okay so far. There's the dude that hits you hard, the dude that hits you really hard, and the dude with lots of little dudes. I have faith that the scenarios will get better with time as they have with the other FFG LCGs and that's when I expect Marvel Champions to show its stuff

EDIT: Lacked long-term staying power. Games played themselves once you understood how your hero worked. The villains did very little to switch the game up even after adding multiple expansions

If you are into living card games and can look past this, it's probably a great game, if not massively underproduced for the price.

The replayability would be high if you can enjoy building your deck before you actually play. But even then, for it being a base game, it included very little. Considering how much can be stuffed into some games for a similar price, this seemed like a cash grab with very little effort thrown at it, other than throwing a Marvel theme on an already used formula.

While the deck building could absolutely be enjoyable, for me, who's entire strategy just worked around 'throw in all of your hero cards, all of one archetype, add in a few staples and go' with a tiny bit of adjustment on top, I didn't find much fun or real exploration to be had in the deckbuilding, especially since Aggression and Protection are really weak in the base box compared to Justice and Leadership, and some cards are just naff - who would ever realistically use Tenacity? It's screaming for a few more cards to add in some wackier strategies, but I just don't really have the interest in buying expansions to 'make it good' after the base box cost me $80AUD.

I don't mind the actual gameplay being a bit more number crunchy than thematic (I like SotM after all) but the two above major problems really did send it a bit awry for me. If I can find Sinister Motives for cheap, and it can reinvigorate the deckbuilding for me, maybe it'll get higher, but I've never been a fan of recommending a game and then saying "you need to get expansions to make it REALLY good".

A wonderful game. I grew up playing trading card games (mtg, yu-gi-oh, and Pokemon) so deckbuilding is extremely fun to me. For that reason, this game is definitely expensive to get into and get a bunch of expansions for (each hero is $12-15 depending where you buy them from, scenarios range from $16-20, etc.). However, even with expansions, it is much cheaper than the trading card games I played growing up, and I love that I can find specific cards or heroes I want to play and just buy individual packs (knowing exactly what I am going to get). Initial Rating: 7.5 (May 2025)

• Years ago, I decided to stop buying LCG games, as they publish too much content and there’s simply no time to play it all. The only one I really played was Netrunner, and even though I loved that game, I ended up selling everything. The only allowable exceptions are cooperative LCGs, which I still have high hopes for. I also LOVE Sentinels of the Multiverse and (recently) I played Slay the Spire: The Board Game, which I liked a lot. Because of that, I thought Marvel Champions: The Card Game was a game for me—and it still can be—but I didn’t enjoy much of my first play, which was an unpleasant surprise. I own most of the game’s content (I only stopped purchasing around a year ago), so I was really hoping it would click.

• Marvel Champions is obviously based on the Marvel comics universe, which I have never explored. Everything I know of Marvel I know from the movies. Each player takes on the role of a famous superhero (Spider-Man, Iron Man, Captain Marvel, etc.) and must work together to defeat a villain before their evil scheme succeeds. The formula is similar´s to SOTM. You flip between your hero and alter ego sides (which is novel and brilliant), play cards for powers and upgrades, and react to the villain’s behavior each round. I guess the game does a solid job of capturing the comic book feel.

• Gameplay is basically hand management and action optimization, mixed with a sort of tactical puzzle each turn (just like SOTM and Slay the Spire). You play cards from your hand by discarding others to pay their costs (a RFTG system I really like), and then use those cards to attack, thwart, defend, etc. From my only play, I saw several cards repeated between my deck and my partner’s deck, which is a disappointment. I was expecting fully asymmetrical decks, but around half of the cards were the same. I dislike this a lot. Also, the game feels too long for what it is. Perhaps I was tired that night and I will give it another play, but when we won I didn’t feel much emotion.

• Since my Magic: The Gathering days, I’ve never really liked assembling my own deck. I used to just wait for tournament results and copy whatever won. I’m not sure how deckbuilding really works here yet, but I’m glad I can just pick a preconstructed deck and play. That’s a big plus for me. The older I get, the least amount of deckbuilding I want to do.

• The luck factor is definitely present—card draws can make or break a turn—but that’s to be expected in a co-op card game, and I enjoy it. In fact, the harder the game the better, so luck doesn’t bother me in cooperative games.

• Best with 2 players. I won’t play it with 3 players—too much downtime—and I’m not a solo player (unless I can get it in an app form).

• The replay value is VERY high. There’s a huge amount of content—heroes, villains, modular sets—and tons of combinations to try out. I probably own more of it than I’ll ever play, which bothers me, and perhaps I will end up selling it. I have played lots of SOTM and I still haven’t played it all.

Bottom line, Marvel Champions: The Card Game has been a disappointment so far. It’s probably my own fault as I expected too much from it. In any case, the game is a cooperative card game with tons of content and a great Marvel theme, so I can recommend it without reservation. I still have hopes for the game and I hope my initial playthrough was a fluke somehow. The hero decks feel too similar (a shame), and playtime can drag, especially with more players. As things stand, the game didn’t blow me away. I didn’t hate it, but I also didn’t feel excited to keep playing after my first session. Both Sentinels of the Multiverse and Slay the Spire are superior IMO. A decent solo or two player coop game that can be surprising difficult to get to the table and has some lazy card design. Not only are there reprinted cards between hero packs, some of these cards are reprinted from previous LCGs.

Game balance comes at the expense of card flair: most being less memorable than your average MTG card, and can build up to a cluttered table and a decent amount of upkeep.

Art is hit and miss (most of it lifted from comics), but the graphic design and card layout are well done.

Meaningful deck building comes after a buy in of around $150 (MSRP) and even then isn't very interesting (the game has strict deck building limitations to keep the game accessible/balanced which reduces card synergies). Terminology and timing can be clunky. The only way to flesh out aspects (the four suits of the game, essentially) you like playing with is to buy hero packs, which can be frustrating/expensive/addicting/fun. God help you if you like aggression as you'll be stuck staring at the Hulk, Valkyrie and Thor packs that range from downright awful to acquired taste. (Edit: consequent aggression packs improved)

Some modules in this box are required to play other scenario packs/campaigns which is mostly unnecessary/predatory. The seven standard encounter cards for example should just be reprinted in the campaign expansions so people can pick any starting point they wish. They reprint the three basic resource cards for each hero pack and I don't see how this is any different. It would also cut down on the card separating needed to prep encounters.

These five heroes are a great selection, which even if some are weak in the larger meta of the game (She Hulk) they are fun to play with. Don't worry, Captain Marvel and Black Panther are quite strong so you can find a difficulty that is right for you. The villains aren't as unique as later expansions, but are decent.

Minor complaint: status cards should have been tokens, and some tokens should have been dice.

While I enjoy the game, it suffers from drab aspect card design that is too often subtle variations of previous cards. I went in expecting the deckbuilding fun to grow significantly as the card pool increased but on top of straight reprints in hero packs there are too many cards themelessly restricted by keyword or simply uninteresting. The underlying math to the game pierces the theme's veil too frequently and makes the game less interesting.

7/10: Fun, while grossly overrated. Pros: I enjoy the modular nature of the game, taking pieces to mix and match together for villains, creating interesting and unique situations. I enjoy the variety of heroes, and how they can play differently based on their abilities, and I really appreciate the challenge this game poses. For both better and worse, playing true solo (1 player as 1 hero) feels like a puzzle, where certain combinations of heroes and aspect decks simply won't work, while others have a high chance of success. Cons: I have the core box, 3 hero packs, and an expansion and I really expected more from this game at this point. Some of the aspects are still awful, specifically protection. The 'deckbuilding' is extremely limited, as there are very clearly better cards than others, which will comprise most hero decks. It needs far more expansions to be purchased for there to be a variety of different ways to play the same aspect each time. Instead of feeling complete with what I have, and that buying more would be more variety of content that I already enjoy, its more like getting more would fix fundamental problems in its design, which is an awful model for a game - making it needlessly and endlessly expensive. It also doesn't help that plenty of the early hero packs and expansions are out of print, and cost a significant amount of money that is just not reasonable or sane to expect new players to dish out for. While I still enjoy the game, I am on the fence as to if it is worth ever buying more.

This is a messy game. Card interactions are not always entirely clear (FFG card wording!), games can be swingy, timing and interruptions add complexity, and the table state is frequently a mess with many cards in play that players need to track and remember. But, it somehow still frequently and consistently delivers a fun, challenging experience that our group keeps returning to.

It's just as satisfying played solo (but not true solo), or up to 4 players.

Deckbuilding presents an ever-present twist and challenge, or building themey, pre-set decks both works. As an experienced gamer with many hundreds of games, I prefer to keep this light and accessible rather than a lifestyle game, but it has still been played almost 100 times at this point.

Never great value (since it's an LCG), but very consistently good fun.

Edit: We're well over 200 play in, and while I still can't quite articulate why, I pretty much always enjoy playing this. Perhaps it is just better than the sum of its parts?

I could see pairing it down to choice characters and scenarios, and I've never gotten into deck building in this game, but I don't see it ever fully leaving my collection.

I don't see myself selling this at any point, I have almost all content from Xmen and earlier, and plan to continue collecting when I am able.
In many ways you could argue this is the best LCG of all time. I enjoy LCGs as an accessible and convenient alternative to TCGs.

My most-played game and my favorite for multiple years in a row, even though it doesn't have miniatures.
